definitions.definition: To maintain , or keep in existence .
examples: The professor had trouble sustaining students’ interest until the end of her lectures.
The city came under sustained attack by enemy forces.
Sam managed to sustain his erection for two straight hours.

definitions.definition: To encourage or sanction (something). (The addition of quotations indicative of this usage is being sought:)
To experience or suffer ( an injury , etc. ).
examples: The building sustained major damage in the earthquake.

definitions.definition: To confirm , prove , or corroborate ; to uphold .
examples: to sustain a charge, an accusation, or a proposition

definitions.definition: To allow, accept, or admit (e.g. an objection or motion) as valid.
To keep from falling; to bear ; to uphold ; to support .
examples: A foundation sustains the superstructure; an animal sustains a load; a rope sustains a weight.

definitions.definition: To aid , comfort , or relieve ; to vindicate .

main_definition: ( transitive ) To maintain , or keep in existence .
secondary_definitions: ( transitive ) To provide for or nourish .
( transitive ) To encourage or sanction (something). (The addition of quotations indicative of this usage is being sought:)
( transitive ) To experience or suffer ( an injury , etc. ).
( transitive ) To confirm , prove , or corroborate ; to uphold .
( law , of a judge ) To allow, accept, or admit (e.g. an objection or motion) as valid.
To keep from falling; to bear ; to uphold ; to support .
To aid , comfort , or relieve ; to vindicate .
